newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SA Druggists sells 6 drugs to U.S. firm.
newsitem.headline: SA Druggists sells 6 drugs to U.S. firm.

text.p: South African Druggists Ltd (SAD) said on Wednesday it had agreed to sell six drugs to U.S. pharmaceuticals group Wyeth-Ayerst/Whitehall International for an undisclosed sum.
SAD had originally bought the licenses for the drugs from Wyeth and the reacquisition by their first owners will see Wyeth re-enter the South African market for the first time since 1989.

"(The deal) facilitates Wyeth-Ayerst/Whitehall's return to South Africa, while securing and extending SAD's relationship with that company well beyond its origiunal horizon," said Peter Beningfield, SAD's chief executive.
SAD will continue to manufacture the drugs on behalf of Wyeth, a unit of giant U.S. firm American Home Products Inc.
The drugs' licensing agreement would have lapsed in 1999. The deal also provides for an extension of manufacturing and marketing rights to 2006 for Wyeth drugs retained by SAD.
The drugs reacquired by Wyeth are female hormone replacement therapies Premarin and Prempak, anti-depressant Efexor and self-medications Anadin, Advil and Preparation H.

SAD will retain oral contraceptives Minulet, Tri-Minulet, Triphasil, Nordette and Biphasil. The firm will also keep Ativan, Dristan, Mucaine, Normison, Isordil, Serepax, Postoval, Denorex and child nutritional products SMA, S26 and Infasoy.
